instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.D7010: What is D7010? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year retina model macbook pros, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC: What is SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC? SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC is a voltage that is created if SMC_BC_ACOK & PP3V42_G3H are both present that powers the chipset for the onewire circuit that allows the SMC to talk to the charger on the SYS_ONEWIRE line. This is necessary for the magsafe charger to have a light on it. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
With battery connected the charger light will after 30 seconds or so turn off. MacBook will still stay on and run but battery no longer charging.
I then have to remove the charger from the mains and count to 20/30 seconds before the charger will work again.
If I plug the charger back in the same thing will happen.
With battery connected PPBUS is 11.33v (which is wrong) should be 12.56
If I disconnect battery PPBUS back to normal.
The board must of has some work done on it in the past as it's been run through an ultrasonic ( I can tell)
Can't see any signs of corrosion although the dc-in port was burnt out when client dropped it off.

Have tried SMC/PRAM resets. Have tried a new battery. Have not tried an SMC reflow yet

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
"With battery connected PPBUS is 11.33v (which is wrong) should be 12.56"
Do NOT make wrong assumptions so easy.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage depends by battery charge level, if is connected!

Did you try known good DCIN board?
I'm not sure if you said it was burnt.
Your english is not easy to understand; try a better translation, please.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
HI, Yes tried a new DC-IN Board and a new battery still same issue.
Sorry about the good English

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Also tried multiple chargers

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Have tried replacing <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, Reflowed SMC, Replaced <DIODE>D7010</DIODE> and replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> but problem still persists.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
Don't go so fast, or you risk to fry the board.
Put some logic on your job.

First, check continuity between <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and central pin of Magsafe connector.
If good, post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages.

Just in case, check voltage and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
Can you be more specific regarding continuity test? Which pin on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and which central pin on Magsafe please?
Thanks

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
The schematic is VERY CLEAR.
Which pin do you think have in common DCIN board, <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and J7000???
Apart of ground, of course...

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Adapter Sense pin6 on J7000 and pin5 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> ??

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
How this can assure good contact with central pin of Magsafe connector???
DCIN board has 1-2 small resistors/coils in series in that line.
I hope you don't need DCIN schematic to find them.

As you already tried (supposed) good DCIN board, your problem should be on MLB.
However, to avoid J6700 failure, I still recommend to check directly between <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and Magsafe connector (on DCIN board).

"If good, post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages."
Don't forget...

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
What is J6700 ??? I have checked from the middle pin on MagSafe to Pin 5 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and there is no problem with continuity.
Do you want <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages without battery plugged in?
Thanks

Note " I hope you don't need DCIN schematic to find them. " lol that's really funny hahahaha :)

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
Magsafe light must come amber without battery.
Be sure to use original 60-85W Magsafe 2 charger.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> Readings with MagSafe plugged in amber light (no battery)

Pin 1 - <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL> = 3.395v
Pin 2 - Ground = 0v
Pin 3 - Unconnected = 0v
Pin 4 - <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> = 3.373v
Pin 5 - <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> = 3.373v

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:

We try to find why Magsafe light goes off; don't you want to check voltage then?

threads.message:

If you get the light, do you think that <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> can have bad voltages?

"check voltage and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus"
Still pending...

Did you try known good battery?

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
With battery ONLY I get the following:-

SCL = 3.383v   .496
SDA = 3.383v  .494

Yes have tried with different known good batteries.

If I plug the charger in the light goes out one second before I get USB activity and then the voltages are not stable on SCL and SDA.

SCL & SDA fluctuate from 2.81 to 3.38v

To answer your question " If you get the light, do you think that <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> can have bad voltages? " I think NO and that means <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> Good?

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
Possibly, that's the reason I asked about SCL/SDA and known good battery.
However, is better to get <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages when the problem appears.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: When the problem happens all voltages on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> are ZERO

threads.message: Then post <CHIP>U7001</CHIP> voltages at same time.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> Voltages
[B]MagSafe Only[/B]
Pin 1 - <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 3.395
Pin 2 - <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 3.150
Pin 3 - GND = 0
Pin 4 - <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL> = 3.395
Pin 5 - <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.395
[B]Battery Only[/B]
Pin 1 - <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 0
Pin 2 - <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 0
Pin 3 - GND = 0
Pin 4 - <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL> = 0
Pin 5 - <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.391
[B]Battery + Charger[/B]
Pin 1 - <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 0
Pin 2 - <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 0
Pin 3 - GND = 0
Pin 4 - <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL> = 0
Pin 5 - <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.391

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
Put some logic on your job and avoid wasting time!
Any reason to measure <CHIP>U7001</CHIP> with battery alone?
Did you ever see a Magsafe light on, in such case?

You lose <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>, good enough to lose the Magsafe light too.
Post basic <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> voltages in that case; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 15, 19, 20, 27.
Be sure no short between <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>/50.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Should I have the battery and magsafe pugged in when measuring the voltages on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> ?

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
You've said to get the problem ONLY when both charger and battery are connected.
Now make a guess, please...

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
[B]<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> with charger and battery connected[/B]
pin 1 =  .019
pin 2 = .078
pin 3 = .019
pin 9 = 0
pin 12 = 3.390
pin 13 = 3.360
pin 15 = .060
pin 19 = 0
pin 20 = 0
pin 27 = 10.55

How do I check for a short between <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7150</RESISTOR> please?

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
"pin 2 = .078"
Missing DCIN voltage.
Post <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> voltages.

Possibly original charger detects leakage, or overload.
Post <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage only with charger.
Did you test with fake charger, or lab PSU?

Check resistance over <CAPACITOR>C7120</CAPACITOR>/50.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> charger only = 12.57
With lab PSU only and NO battery I get green then amber light but I can't get the board to power on (have tried powering on using the pads and also with keyboard)
It will, however, power on with lab PSU + Battery and the light does stay on the magsafe (amber)

I don't know how to give you the voltage readings for <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> as my board view shows a different orientation of the chip from my actual logic board.

<CAPACITOR>C7120</CAPACITOR> = 28.49 mega ohms
<CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR> = 3.8 ohms

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
"<CAPACITOR>C7120</CAPACITOR> = 28.49 mega ohms"
Check <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22 and their traces.
Fix that; should be good enough to solve the problem.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> and 22 were open circuit. Replaced both and problem solved.
You are an absolute genius! I don't know how you do it but I will read through our discussion and try and understand why you asked me to do the things you asked me to do.

Thank you very much!
